thread.title: Matt Harvey, Mets win Game 1, put in familiar place
thread.title_full: Matt Harvey, Mets win Game 1, put Cubs in familiar place | Chicago Sun-Times

author: | emailAddress.indexOf('@') == -1) {errorString = 'Please enter your email address';} var isError = false; if (errorString.length > 0) isError = true; if (isError) alert(errorString); return !isError;}
title: Matt Harvey, Mets win Game 1, put in familiar place
text:
NEW YORK – Been there, done that, say the Cubs.
A bunch of Chicago baseball players who never experienced the rush of playoff baseball before this month shrugged off a Game 1 loss to the New York Mets and a hard-throwing Matt Harvey, who made a 4-2 victory look easy for much of his start Saturday night Championship Series opener.
“Yeah, it’s just one game,” said Kyle Schwarber, the rookie who made Cubs postseason homer history just four months to the day after he made his big-league starting debut.
“We’ll see what happens [in Game 2],” said young shortstop Javy Baez, who was in the minors until last month.
Whether they’ve actually become experts in postseason savvy in just six playoff games or are just blissfully oblivious to the heat of October baseball, it’s worked for them so far.
But as sure as the cold wind hit them in the face in the first inning, and as sure as Harvey put them down in order through the first four innings, this task at hand for the Cubs in this round looks a lot different than the last round against a beat-up and familiar Cardinals team.
This is not the same Mets team the Cubs have beaten the last nine consecutive regular-season games. And the four-headed monster of first- and second-year power pitchers in the Mets rotation might be the deepest, nastiest starting crew in this year’s 10-team playoff field.
“Probably it is,” Cubs catcher Miguel Montero said. “Now we’ve got [rookie Noah] Syndergaard. I know he’s the ‘soft-‘throwing right-hander, right? He only throws 99.”
“It is that good,” said of the Mets’ starting pitching. “We knew that coming in. We have Jake [Arrieta] pitching tomorrow. They know how good he is.
“Listen, honestly, our guys were fine tonight.”
And they have done this before, losing the Division Series opener to the Cardinals before winning the next three to advance.
And they eventually got to Harvey – with Schwarber knocking him out of the game when he hit Harvey’s 97th pitch halfway to LaGuardia Airport.
Their $155 million playoff veteran, Jon Lester, had trouble keeping pace with Harvey – allowing a pair of homers and four runs in 6 2/3 innings.
“Once again, I put our team behind the eight ball against a really good pitcher,” said Lester, who lost the St. Louis opener, and on this night kicked himself especially hard for giving up the go-ahead run in the fifth after Starlin Castro’s double on a misplayed line drive drove home Rizzo to tie it in the top of the inning.
“That’s the game. I’ve got to do a better job of getting our guys back in the dugout,” Lester said.
“Hopefully Jake can pick me up tomorrow.”
After hitting 12 homers in their first five playoff games against Pittsburgh and St. Louis, the Cubs managed one by Schwarber, on a night the temperature started in the upper 40s and dropped throughout the game – cold enough that right-fielder Jorge Soler, Baez and Castro all wore blue ski masks in the field.
Schwarber’s home run gave him four for the postseason – tying the Mets’ Daniel Murphy (who hit one in the first) for most this postseason. He also has hit homers in three consecutive games, tying Alex Gonzalez (2003) for the franchise record.
And now they come back and try to steal home-field advantage against Syndergaard.
“You can’t live and die on one game,” first baseman Anthony Rizzo said. “We did live and die on one game a few weeks ago [against Pittsburgh in the wild-card game]. So now we get to breathe a little bit.
“We did lose our first game in St. Louis and bounced back. So I expect nothing less out of this team.”
Harvey retired the first 12 Cubs he faced, half on strikeouts, before hitting Rizzo with a pitch leading off the sixth.
Castro followed with his drive over the head of center fielder Juan Lagares – who started in before retreating, too late.
The hit tied the game, but when Castro failed to get out of the box quickly, he wound up on second instead of having a shot at a triple (he said after the game he didn’t believe he would have had three bases either regardless).
It proved potentially costly when Baez singled to left one batter later, and Castro was thrown out by Yoenis Cespedes at the plate.
The Mets regained the lead in the bottom of the inning on a pair of one-out singles and Chicago native Curtis Granderson’s two-out, run-scoring hit to center. In between, third baseman Kris Bryant dropped the ball taking it from his glove on a potential inning-ending double play.
Travis d’Arnaud made it 3-1 with the Mets’ second homer of the game, hitting the giant apple behind the center field fence.
The Mets, who clearly didn’t believe Lester’s two throws to first in September proved he had cured his throwing yips, tried to take advantage throughout the game, adding a big insurance run in the seventh after Lagares stole third with one out.
Granderson followed with a sacrifice fly for a 4-1 lead.
